head.title: A Radio That Charges Its Own Batteries

hedline.hl1: A Radio That Charges Its Own Batteries

abstract.p: Plug In, rechargeable radio by Lexon in France, will be available in United States in May; photo (Currents column) (S)

block.p: Plug In, a rechargeable radio by Lexon in France, won the award for ''best discovery'' last month in the Now Design section of the Maison & Objets show in Paris. The brightly colored plastic radio's antenna is a three-inch circular wire halo that folds behind the unit when it is not in use. Plug In plays while plugged into a wall outlet but can run untethered for 15 hours once its batteries are charged.

Plug In, a rechargeable radio by Lexon in France, won the award for ''best discovery'' last month in the Now Design section of the Maison & Objets show in Paris. The brightly colored plastic radio's antenna is a three-inch circular wire halo that folds behind the unit when it is not in use. Plug In plays while plugged into a wall outlet but can run untethered for 15 hours once its batteries are charged.

Inconspicuous dials, located on the side, control the stations and volume. The Plug In comes in chartreuse, silver or blue and will cost about $60 when it is available in May in stores across the country; (888) 445-3966 for store locations.
